content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Creative challenge.

This is a workable description, but for me it could use some clarification: You need to output the outline of the shape as a sequence of vertices. Start from the top-leftmost point of the first line of text and follow the shape's boundary in a clockwise direction.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Insanely interesting puzzle: cracked my head trying to figure out a reasonable solution and ended up with 85 lines of convoluted Python code and a huge sigh of relief. I have a feeling that this is between the border of Medium and Hard difficulty, but that could also be my opinion because I struggled with this one a lot, so you can change it if you too feel like it.

Also, looking back from my initial struggle to understand the question language due to the phrase "pixel grid" being mentioned (and that being clarified afterwards), I would suggest rewriting it just a bit more into something like:

Given a shape plotted in a coordinate axis (containing H x W squares) using a set of points, determine and output the points used to draw the shape, starting from the top-leftmost vertex of the shape, towards the right in a clockwise manner. The top-leftmost vertex of the grid is (0, 0), with the X-coordinate increasing towards the right and Y-coordinate increasing downwards. A single square represented in the input is made of S units of length.

There are no hollow spaces or diagonally touching squares (forming the shape)

Are you sure that both your description and your approach/idea for the solution are correct? The outline drawn by your output sometimes goes out of bounds of the actual shape.
It would also be nice if you could clarify if you want the outline outside or inside the actual shape.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: it's a good, difficult and fun puzzle.... follow the clockwise direction and determine the corners is very challenging... very interesting that a particular case of this puzzle is to determine the path of a draw maze.

Goal
* Please rewrite as follows:

Given a shape in an [[H]] x [[W]] pixel grid, where {{#}} represents a part of the shape, and {{.}} represents an empty space, you need to output the outline of the shape by starting from the top-left point of the shape and following the shape's boundary in a clockwise direction.

X-coordinates increase towards the right. Y-coordinates increase towards the bottom. The origin (0, 0) is at the top-left corner of the grid.

Input
* Please format "Next [[H]] lines" in <<bold>>.

* Please delete "Output (etc) X Y coords".

Output
* Please change as follows:

<<[[N]] lines>>: Two space-separated integers, representing the X and Y coordinates of a vertex of the shape's outline (and there are [[N]] vertices in total).

Stub generator
* Suggest to change "points" to "vertex".

Constraints
* Depending on whether there will be more cases, the upper limits of H, W and N may be reduced to better reflect the actual cases.

Cover picture
* Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.

Thank you

It is still work in progress, adding more test cases, statement not yes complete, working on cover now.
Much appreciate your comments

Thank you Manuel

I am glad that you liked the puzzle and it was also fun for me to come up with this one. You need to figure out a few things to solve it, so, yes, it's a bit tricky. If you check out my solution, my trick was to "smudge" the shape vertically and horizontally by one "pixel" and then figure out the corners.

Thank you Ajaiy

Every shape can be drown with a single stroke. I avoided hollow shapes or diagonal touches of the pixels, it gets ambiguous what to draw first of what direction to follow.

Final X and y of the output must be multiplied with "pixel size" - that's why it appears to be out of bounds. Size of the shape and the output are not the same, but amplified with pixel size.

Is this more clear or I need to update the statement with more info?
I will look into your comments and surely upadate the statement. It needs to be clear to everyone.

David, thank you for your comment.

I have updated the statement to be more clear. "Pixel size" is also something people may find confusing, so I hope it is better now.
Thank you David. This is my first approved CodinGame contribution, I much appreciate your effort.

Also, I am glad that you liked it so much. It is borderline hard difficulty, but the reason why I set it to medium is because there are no heavy computing, recursion or something similar. That said, it's a bit hard to figure out the solution.

Of course I didn't mean an offset of 9-10 pixels ðŸ˜„

Let me just make sure of some things:
1) The X-coordinate is specified first, and then the Y-coordinate.
2) X-coordinate increases towards the right, and Y-coordinate increases towards the bottom.
3) The top-left of the grid in question is the coordinate (0, 0)
4) Dividing both the given coordinates by the pixel size gives the conventional coordinate system.
Now this all implies that in the first example "Triangle", the second coordinate specified in the output is (2, 0) (after division), which is the pixel in the first row and the third column.

Wait, where is the third column?

I understand your logic and this is ,y explanation.
Pixels in the shape are representing the centre of each pixel. The (20, 0) coordinate is the point that is shared between the top right corner of (1,0)) in shape grid and the top left corner of (2, 0) in shape grid. So, we cannot mix centre of pixel and the corners of the outline. They are related, but the corner can belong to up to 4 pixels - centres. When dividing the corners with pixel size, you cannot determine to what pixel centre it belongs to.

Thank you for your comment, I really appreciate your interesting point of view.

Oh, that makes sense. Thank you for clarifying.
I'll try the puzzle and approve it then; it looks quite new.
